abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Additional Financing for
            the Health Care System Improvement Project for Montenegro
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk
            to development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            need for quick project preparation must be balanced with the
            quality of project at entry. The project was prepared quite
            rapidly, with only nine months from concept review to Board
            approval. Additionally, the country situation at preparation
            stage was still fluid, coming out of a turbulent phase of
            its history. Agreed institutional arrangements, government
            commitment and a viable single agency are basic
            prerequisites for a successful project implementation. Both
            the Bank and the government need to involve proper expertise
            in different areas, to ensure a smooth implementation of
            project activities. Lack of a proper Monitoring and
            Evaluation (M&E) design raises questions on the overall
            quality of project design. Close coordination with other
            development partners is very important. Health sector
            reforms are long-term and quite complex.
